awd_titl_txt: Student Travel Support to 3D Printing of Polymeric Composites & Hybrid Systems Symposium at American Chemical Society National Meeting; San Diego, California; March 20-24, 2022
awd_abstract_narration:
This award provides travel support for students, post-docs and young faculty to attend and participate in the Symposium on "3D Printing of Polymeric Composites and Hybrid Systems " at the Spring American Chemical Society (ACS) national meeting in San Diego, CA, in March 20-24, 2022. The symposium focuses on new research in the field of polymer processing, composite and hybrid systems and additive manufacturing. The students present through oral and poster sessions their latest research results to the polymer processing, advanced manufacturing and broader engineering communities. Priority is given to student and young faculty participants who are women or who come from underrepresented minority groups. This approach promotes diverse participation at the conference, in the short term, and in STEM fields, in the long term. This award benefits the nation through the education of a skilled and diverse manufacturing workforce, which is better prepared to provide transformative solutions the challenges in their chosen fields.

This participant support is expected to benefit the students' professional, scientific and technical development. Attendance at the conference gives the students and young faculty a broader view of the polymer processing, composite and hybrid systems, additive manufacturing and engineering profession and of state-of-the-art research in their fields via access to several technical and professional development talks by leading domestic and international speakers. In particular, the symposium will discuss sustainability, recycling and remanufacturing. It will also discuss 3D printing strategies to mitigate polymer waste. Students enhance their communication skills through oral and poster presentations, in-depth discussions of their work with peers in their fields. This interactive experience significantly broadens student education, increases their enthusiasm for their research topic, acquaints them with expectations for scientific careers, and exposes them to new approaches for innovative research.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
Overview:

Additive manufacturing, also called 3D printing, is the process of depositing one layer over the other based on 3D-modeled data. Different from conventional subtractive manufacturing, additive manufacturing has the merits of low waste materials, short lead time, and highly customized design. Besides, additive manufacturing, known as delocalized processing, does not depend on global logistics that respond quickly to disasters or pandemics. As a result, the fundamental understanding of 3D printing mechanisms and their different applications to satisfy scientific or social needs are critical. Therefore, this project focused on bringing together academic scholars, industry researchers, federal agency program managers, and students to discuss the current state-of-the-art and brainstorm possible solutions to future challenges in 3D printing, especially 3D printed composites and hybrid materials. This project provided financial support to junior faculties and students from underrepresented groups to attend professional conferences. The symposium on "3D Printing-Enabled Polymeric Composites and Hybrid Systems" was hosted at the 2022 Spring American Chemical Society (ACS) National Meetings & Expos (March 20-24, 2022, San Diego, CA). The funded candidates include (i) ten faculty members from Princeton University, Georgia Tech, the University of Colorado at Colorado Springs, the University of North Carolina at Charlotte, Stony Brook University, Purdue University, Clemson University, Pen State, and Angelo State University, (ii) five students from Delaware University, Texas AM, Binghamton University, Washington State University, and West Virginia University, and (iii) five minority students from ASU. This symposium included 100+ talks in ten sessions co-chaired by seven experts from U.S. universities and national labs.

 

Intellectual Merit:

This project has provided a platform for scientists and engineers working in the 3D printing fields to present a fundamental understanding of materials (e.g., polymers, nanoparticles, ceramics, metals). Topics are relevant to composites and hybrids based on different polymers and reinforcement fillers, including mixing, separation, hybridization, degradation, upcycling, downcycling, and mechanics. These topics involved material physics, polymer chemistry, nanoparticle engineering, thermodynamics, kinetics, 3D printing instrument design, measurement science, and precision engineering. The uses of 3D printed materials and morphologies were reported to be in different categories, such as structural supports, thermal conduction or dissipation, electronics, optics, and biomedical/pharmaceutical engineering. The design of monomers/polymers and assembly of unique 3D printers to enhance material reclaimability, recyclability, and repairability was also covered.

 

Broader Impacts:

Various 3D printing methods have been broadly used in lightweight composites, heat exchangers, circuit boards, metasurfaces, and regenerative medicine. Thus, this conference symposium invited program managers and leaders from the National Science Foundation, National Institute of Health, Air Force Research Laboratories, Department of Energy National Energy Technology Laboratory, Carbon3D, Hybrid Manufacturing Technologies, and MxD to comprehensively talk about the achievements in the past decades and current bottlenecks in this field. Other sessions described the (i) 3D printed polymers and composites, (ii) designing novel materials for additive manufacturing, (iii) excellent faculty with diversity in 3D printing research, (iv) bioplotting, biofabrication,  and their biomedical and healthcare applications, (v) 3D and 4D printing for intelligent systems, (vi) young scholars and students in 3D printing for enhanced diversity and inclusion, (vii) 3D printable carbons, ceramics, metals, and their composites, (viii) 3d printing for energy, sustainability, and other smart applications, and, (ix) functional applications. These sessions overviewed the commonly used 3D printing, e.g., stereolithography, fused deposition modeling, direct ink writing, selective laser sintering, selective laser melting, and inkjet, among many others. More importantly, junior faculties from R1/R2 universities and undergraduate colleges, as well as students from diverse backgrounds in general engineering received training on professionalism and state-of-the-art 3D printing research. The students involved in this project were primarily those from the colored, disabled, and female groups.

 


Last Modified: 09/27/2022
Modified by: Kenan Song
